text:
This fortnight's top free and paid-for apps for Android and iOS phones and
tablets

App of the Fortnight

VIDEO

Vimeo Create

bit.ly/vimeodroid497

bit.ly/vimeoios497

#6 #11

Once upon a time, only successful businesses could afford to use video as a
promotional tool. These days, however, the format has been democratised since
most of us carry a high-quality HD (or even 4K) video camera in our pockets.
This makes it easy for small businesses and individuals to get great shots to
promote themselves - or just show off on social media.

However, filming the footage is one thing - making it look like a proper piece
of promotion is another skill altogether. That's why video-streaming service
Vimeo has released this new app. Vimeo Create is fresh out of beta and it
allows users to make professional-looking promo clips, either by starting with
some of Vimeo's pre-built templates or by building one from scratch using your
own footage.

Creating videos is a simple, step-by-step process - just select your clips,
add a cool-looking style, then layer on some music and let the tool's smart
video creator do the rest. The results can be pretty attention-grabbing, and
you can tweak any elements that aren't quite to your liking.

The app is completely free to download and use but, If you're not already
signed up to one of Vimeo's paid-for subscription services, you'll need to
upgrade your membership to save and publish your clips to Vimeo's streaming
platform. Vimeo Pro costs £16 per month, though one way to get around this is
to use the 30-day free trial you get when you first sign up. It's also worth
noting that some features, including adding logos and branding to your clips,
require Vimeo's more expensive (£40 per month) Business subscription.

Our rating ★★★★★

MINI WORKSHOP

Create professional videos with Vimeo Create

1 Launch Vimeo Create and you'll be asked to join: if you don't have an
account, choose one of the options to sign up; if you do, tap the small 'Log
in' option at the bottom of the screen or tap Skip (topright) to use the tool
without signing in for now. You'll be taken to the main screen, where you can
choose or search В for predesigned templates |2 that you can customise.

2 To create a video from scratch, tap the green plus-sign (+) icon, then press
Allow to let Vimeo Create access videos and other media stored on your device.
Give your video a name and tap OK. At the top of the screen, press the 'Camera
roll', Stock, Google Photos or Uploads tabs IT to select your source, then
browse for a clip you want and tap its thumbnail. |2 Tap Next. ⅛

3 Press Add on the next screen to add further clips or text. Vimeo Business
users can also add branding here. For the time being, just tap Next, then
select a Style from the pre-built selection and tap Next again. You'll be
offered a selection of licensed tunes to accompany your video. Press the Play
icon |1 to hear them, then tap the thumbnail 12 to select the tune you want to
use and tap Create. El

TOOLS

AppNotifier

bit. ly/ appnotifier497

#5

Recently, many Android users have noticed that the Play Store has suddenly
stopped showing notifications for updated apps. Initially, there was some
confusion as to whether this was just a bug, but then Google appeared to
confirm that it was an intentional feature change. Either way, it hasn't been
particularly well received and we've heard rumours that Google might be
bringing the feature back. Until then, this app could be the answer - it shows
a notification each time an app is installed or updated on your device.

Our rating ★★★★★

GAME

Chess Ace

bit. ly/ chessdroid497

bit.ly/chessios497

#4.4 4 9

Love chess? Enjoy playing cards? Well, now you can do both, thanks to this
clever game. It's basically a puzzle where you're tasked with navigating a 5 x
5 chessboard using a limited number of chess moves, with the aim being to
collect all the clubs on the board. Things start off simple but soon get
challenging. Chess Ace offers 250 levels and several different skins to choose
from. You can unlock 'ranked play', to compare your achievements with others,
after you've completed a certain number of levels.

Our rating ★★★★★

Lego Legacy: Heroes Unboxed

bit.ly/legodroid497

bit.ly/legoios497

44.4«9

Lego minifigures are eminently collectible, which may be one of the drivers
for developing this new mobile game. Heroes Unboxed is part role-playing game
and part collect-'em-up, with heavy shades of Pokemon. The idea is to unlock
and upgrade a team of minifigs to explore and do battle while reconstructing
Piptown, the game's setting. The game is free to play, but some 'grinding'
(performing repetitive tasks) may be required to avoid in-app purchases.

Our rating ★★★★★

SOCIAL

Messenger for iOS

[www.messenger.com](http://www.messenger.com)

9

App updates often add more features but they can also make the app a lot
bigger as a result. However, Facebook appears to have reversed this trend with
the latest update (codenamed Project LightSpeed) for Messenger. The aim here
is downsizing - making the app faster, smaller and simpler. According to the
app's developers (bit.ly/mess497), Messenger's code has been completely
rebuilt and simplified by around 84%, making the app about a quarter of its
original size and around twice as fast. The update is available for iOS but
there's currently no information as to when Android users can expect a similar
streamlining exercise.

Our rating ★★★★★

MUSIC

Spotify for iOS

bit.ly/spotify497

11

Spotify has also implemented a new streamlined look for its mobile app, aimed
at making the interface simpler and easier to navigate. The update (currently
only available for iOS users, with an Android equivalent "coming soon")
introduces a new dual-action Play button that incorporates Shuffle Play as a
kind of sub-button, making it easier to start streaming with a single tap.
There's also a new set of icons incorporated into a toolbar, which Spotify
calls its Action Row. Actions such as 'like', 'play' and 'download' are now
grouped in a central part of the screen, making the app much easier to use
one-handed.

Our rating ★★★★★

NEW APPS WORTH PAYING FOR

TOOLS

Autosync

bit.ly/auto497

Price: £6.99

(varies)

This handy tool lets you sync folders on your device with folders from cloud-
storage accounts. Autosync is currently free to try but it requires payment
when the trial expires.

TOOLS

Tetrd Pro

bit.ly/tetrd497

Price: £5.49

4.1

If your device doesn't support tethering, then this app lets you share its
internet connection with your PC (and vice versa) through a USB cable. There's
also a free time-limited version available.

EDUCATION

Spelling Shed

bit.ly/spellingdroid497

bit.ly/spellingios497

Price: £2.99

9

New on Android, this educational app is designed by teachers and used in
schools worldwide. It gamifies learning to help kids improve their spelling
and have some fun at the same time.

TOOLS

Random Reminder

bit.ly/random497

Price: 99p

4.1

Ever feel daunted by long to-do list and reminder notifications? Then this
could be a useful alternative. Just create a list of tasks and press a button
whenever you need your memory jogged.

GAME

Castlevania: Symphony of the Night

bit.ly/castle497

Price: £2.99

4.4 #9

One of the greatest console games of all time comes to iOS and Android.
Rediscover Dracula's castle on your phone or tablet - if you've never played
it before, you're in for a treat. The app supports controllers, too.

Install this app...

Ruler

bit.ly/ruler497

4.1

Some measuring apps boast flashy augmented-reality abilities but, as our 'Not
this' app proves, these can often result in measurements you can't trust.
Ruler, on the other hand, takes a simple idea - turning your phone screen into
a virtual ruler - and finesses it. The interface is clean and well designed,
you can choose between cm, mm or inches, and there are four different
measuring modes to choose from: point, line, plane and level. Most important
of all, your measurements will all be accurate. Ruler's occasional full-screen
ads are a little annoying but, if you like the app, you can banish these with
a mere £1.19.

...Not this one

Measure Tools - AR Ruler

bit.ly/measure497

Augmented reality can be brilliant when it's used well but, sadly, that's not
the case here. The idea is to measure things in the real world using a virtual
measuring tape, but the app's results are inconsistent (which makes it
completely useless) and - as one disgruntled user points out in a Google Play
review - the adverts are so invasive that they actually cover up the app
buttons at the bottom of the screen.
